revision.text:
{{pp-pc1}} {{Infobox person | name = Wayne Brady | image = Wayne Brady 2015.jpg | caption = Brady in 2015 | birth_name = Wayne Alphonso Brady | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1972|6|2}} | birth_place = [[Columbus, Georgia]], U.S. | occupation = Actor, television personality, comedian, singer, presenter, game show host | years_active = 1990{{ndash}}present | spouse = {{marriage|Diana Lasso
|1993|1995|end=div}}
{{marriage|Mandie Taketa
|1999|2007|end=div}} | children = 1 | television = ''[[The Wayne Brady Show]]'' }} '''Wayne Alphonso Brady''' (born June 2, 1972) is an American actor, singer and [[comedian]] who is a regular on the American version of the [[improvisational comedy]] television series ''[[Whose Line Is It Anyway? (U.S. TV series)|Whose Line Is It Anyway?]]'' He was the host of the daytime talk show ''[[The Wayne Brady Show]]'', the original host of [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]]'s ''[[Don't Forget the Lyrics! (U.S.)|Don't Forget the Lyrics!]]'', and has hosted ''[[Let's Make a Deal]]'' since its 2009 revival. Brady also performed in the [[Tony Award]]-winning musical ''[[Kinky Boots (musical)|Kinky Boots]]'' on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] as Simon and as [[drag queen]] Lola from November 2015 to March 2016. ==Early life== Brady was born in [[Columbus, Georgia]],[https://www.imdb.com/video/cbs/vi2315257625 ''Let's Make A Deal'', episode May 11, 2010 at 9:23 minutes, Wayne Brady says he was born in Columbus, Georgia], imdb.com/video; accessed January 14, 2018. to [[West Indian]] parents,{{cite web|title=The Daily Show with Trevor Noah – February 26, 2018 – Wayne Brady – Full Episode | Comedy Central|url=http://www.cc.com/episodes/1eetib/the-daily-show-with-trevor-noah-february-26--2018---wayne-brady-season-23-ep-23063|website=cc.com|accessdate=28 February 2018}} and moved to [[Orlando, Florida]], as a young child to live with his grandmother and aunt. Brady refers to his grandmother, Valerie Petersen, as his "mom", since she raised him.{{cite web|url=http://www.concordmusicgroup.com/assets/documents01/Artists/Wayne-Brady/PKD-30665/A-Long-Time-Coming-iTunes-Booklet.pdf|title=A Long Time Coming iTunes Booklet (PDF)|author=Brady, Wayne|publisher=concordmusicgroup.com|quote=My mother, Valerie Petersen, the best mother a guy could have.|page=7|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019104003/http://www.concordmusicgroup.com/assets/documents01/Artists/Wayne-Brady/PKD-30665/A-Long-Time-Coming-iTunes-Booklet.pdf|archivedate=2013-10-19}}{{cite journal|title=Wayne Brady|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1355/is_7_103/ai_97450951/|date=2003-02-10|quote=Brady also credits his 72-year-old grandmother, Valerie Peterson [sic], who reared him and whom he affectionately calls 'Mom'...|author=Walker, Nicole|work=Jet|volume=103|issue=7}} Brady is second cousin to professional footballer [[Jozy Altidore]]{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} who currently plays for [[Toronto FC]].{{cite news|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2015/01/16/toronto-fc-acquire-us-international-jozy-altidore-allocation-jermain-defoe|title=Toronto FC acquire US international Jozy Altidore via Allocation, send Jermain Defoe to Sunderland|date=January 16, 2015|publisher=MLSsoccer.com}} At 16, Brady started performing in community theater and at the Orlando improv troupe [[SAK Comedy Lab]], where he first started developing his improv skills. He attended [[Dr. Phillips High School]] in Orlando, where he graduated in 1989. In 1990, he enrolled at the [[University of Miami]].{{cite web|url=http://www.totalspeakers.com/speaker/wayne-brady|title=Wayne Brady|work=Goviva Speakers|accessdate=September 2, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120919064347/http://www.totalspeakers.com/speaker/wayne-brady|archivedate=September 19, 2012|df=}} In 1996, he moved to Los Angeles where he continued developing his acting skills.{{cite web|last=Boedeker|first=Hal|title=Joey Fatone, Wayne Brady form mutual-admiration society|work=[[Orlando Sentinel|OrlandoSentinel.com]]|publisher=Orlando Sentinel Communications|date=2007-07-02|url=http://blogs.orlandosentinel.com/entertainment_tv_tvblog/2007/07/joey-fatone-way.html|accessdate=2008-04-06|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080425033839/http://blogs.orlandosentinel.com/entertainment_tv_tvblog/2007/07/joey-fatone-way.html|archivedate=2008-04-25}} ==Career== {{more citations needed|section|date=January 2018}} Brady was one of the [[improvisational theater]] performers in the original (British) version of ''[[Whose Line Is It Anyway? (UK TV series)|Whose Line Is It Anyway?]]'', along with [[Ryan Stiles]], [[Colin Mochrie]], and host [[Clive Anderson]] in 1998 when the last season was filmed in Hollywood, after which he became a regular on [[Whose Line Is It Anyway? (U.S. TV series)|the American version]], hosted by [[Drew Carey]], which was his first stateside television exposure. In 2003, Brady won a [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Individual Performance in a Variety or Music Program]] for his work on the show, the only person to win the award for a television series, as opposed to a special, since [[Dana Carvey]] in 1993. He went on to star in his own [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] variety show in 2001, ''The Wayne Brady Show'', and a daytime talk show of the same name in 2002, which lasted two seasons and won four [[Daytime Emmy Award]]s, two of which went to Brady for Outstanding Talk Show Host. Brady guest-starred on ''[[The Drew Carey Show]]'' in 1999 and 2000 to take part in "[[Drew Live]]" and "[[Drew Live II]]". On the show, Brady played several games taken from ''Whose Line Is It Anyway?'' for the two episodes with other characters. In 2004, Brady joined the [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] revival of ''[[Chicago (musical)|Chicago]]'', playing the role of lawyer Billy Flynn. He appeared briefly in the final episode of the 2004 season of the comedy ''[[Reno 911!]]''. He guest-starred on the [[Sci Fi Channel (United States)|Sci Fi Channel's]] hit series ''[[Stargate SG-1]]'' as Trelak, the first prime of [[Goa'uld]] System Lord Ares. He made an appearance on ''[[Chappelle's Show]]'', poking fun at his squeaky-clean persona.{{cite episode|title=Episode #2.12|series=Chappelle's Show|serieslink=Chappelle's Show|credits=[[Neal Brennan]] & [[Dave Chappelle]] (writers); [[Neal Brennan]] (director)|network=[[Comedy Central]]|airdate=2004-04-07|season=2|number=12}} Brady wrote and sang the theme song for Disney's animated series ''[[The Weekenders]]''. In 2005, he sang and recorded [[Jim Brickman]]'s original Disney song "Beautiful" (a cover of [[All-4-One]]'s 2002 hit "Beautiful As You") and its Christmas version."Beautiful" from ''The Disney Songbook'' album by [[Jim Brickman]] and Disney's ''Cinderella'' [Special Edition] soundtrack. "Beautiful" (Christmas version) from ''Disney's Princess Christmas Album'' In 2006, Brady became the host of [[TV Land]]'s ''That's What I'm Talking About'', a talk show discussing the role of African-Americans in the entertainment industry. From August 29 to September 29, 2006, Brady hosted the Fox show ''[[Celebrity Duets]]''. Brady made several guest appearances on the CBS sitcom ''[[How I Met Your Mother]]'', playing James Stinson, the [[gay]] brother of [[Neil Patrick Harris]]'s character, [[Barney Stinson]]. Brady has also appeared as a guest star for the MTV show ''[[Wild 'N Out]]'', and lent his voice to the [[Adult Swim]] show ''[[Robot Chicken]]''. Brady guest-starred in the [[CBC Television|CBC]] comedy ''[[Getting Along Famously]]'' alongside his ''Whose Line is It Anyway?'' costar [[Colin Mochrie]]. He has also appeared on the episode "You Don't Know Jack" of the television show ''[[Dirt (TV series)|Dirt]]'', and also guest-starred on ''[[30 Rock]]'' as Steven Black, Liz Lemon's date for the Source Awards. He co-hosted the short-lived [[VH1]] show ''Vinyl Justice'' in 1998. In 2007, he starred in the [[ABC Family]] film ''The List''. He starred in ''Flirt'', a comedy pilot which was not picked up by the network.Dana Slagle, [https://books.google.com/books?id=kDoDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA61&dq=Flirt+%22Wayne+Brady%22&ei=IMiYSbKUMZ2EzgTguYGYDw 61 "Comedic Actor Wayne Brady Demonstrates Versatility In New Movie, 'Crossover'"], ''Jet'' 110.11 (September 18, 2006). Brady guest-starred as [[Julius (Everybody Hates Chris)|Julius Rock]]'s gifted younger brother, Louis, in the sitcom ''[[Everybody Hates Chris]]'', and hosted a singing game show called ''[[Don't Forget the Lyrics!]]'' on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] until its cancellation in June 2009. He performs "Wayne Brady: Making $%!^ up" at the [[The Venetian, Las Vegas|Venetian Hotel]] in [[Las Vegas, Nevada]] four nights a week.{{cite web|url=https://www.songkick.com/venues/825086-wayne-brady-theatre-venetian-casino-hotel-and-resort|title=Wayne Brady Theatre, Venetian Casino, Hotel & Resort Las Vegas, Tickets for Concerts & Music Events 2018 – Songkick|website=www.songkick.com}} He appeared on two episodes of ''Kevin Hill''. Brady's debut album was released on September 16, 2008. Brady's version of [[Sam Cooke]]'s "[[A Change is Gonna Come]]" earned him a [[Grammy Award]] nomination in the [[Best Traditional R&B Vocal Performance]] category.{{cite web|url=http://www.waynebrady.com/news/newsItem.cfm?cms_news_id=40|title=News » Grammy Nomination|publisher=Wayne Brady|date=2008-04-12|accessdate=2010-05-03|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100504175535/http://www.waynebrady.com/news/newsItem.cfm?cms_news_id=40|archivedate=2010-05-04}} Brady started hosting an updated version of the game show ''[[Let's Make a Deal]]'' for CBS in October 2009, which taped at the [[Tropicana Resort and Casino]] in Las Vegas and currently tapes in Los Angeles. The show replaced the soap opera ''[[Guiding Light]]'', which ended its long run. The original host of ''Let's Make a Deal'' was [[Monty Hall]], who served as consultant for the new show until his death in 2017. [[Drew Carey]] currently hosts ''[[The Price Is Right (U.S. game show)|The Price Is Right]]'', and thus, both game shows in the CBS daytime lineup (as of September 2017) hold the distinction of being hosted by an alumnus of ''Whose Line Is It Anyway?'' Brady was the [[List of WWE Raw guest hosts|guest host]] on the May 3, 2010, episode of ''[[WWE Raw]]'', where he was involved in an in-ring segment with [[Adam Copeland|Edge]] and [[Randy Orton]], eventually getting RKO'd by Orton. Later that year, in August, Brady played the role of Tom Collins in a staged production of ''[[Rent (musical)|Rent]]'' at the Hollywood Bowl. The production was directed by Neil Patrick Harris.{{cite web|author=BWW News Desk|title=Brady, Tveit, Astin And Thoms Join RENT At Hollywood Bowl|work=BroadwayWorld.com|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Brady_Tveit_Astin_And_Thoms_To_Lead_RENT_At_Hollywood_Bowl_20100430|accessdate=September 2, 2015}} Brady appeared alongside ''Let's Make a Deal'' announcer [[Jonathan Mangum]] in two episodes of ''[[Fast and Loose (2011 TV series)|Fast and Loose]]'', an improvisational series on [[BBC2]] hosted by [[Hugh Dennis]], in January 2011. Then, with [[Holly Robinson Peete]], he co-hosted the 42nd annual [[NAACP Image Awards]] on March 4, 2011.{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/02/08/wayne-brady-and-holly-robinson-peete-to-host-42nd-naacp-image-awards-friday-march-4-on-fox/81922|publisher=Tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com|title=Wayne Brady and Holly Robinson Peete to Host '42nd NAACP Image Awards' Friday, March 4 on Fox – Ratings|accessdate=2012-01-04}} On May 3, 2011, he appeared on ''[[Dancing With The Stars]]'' as the lead performer in a tribute to [[James Brown]], celebrating what would have been Brown's 78th birthday in the Macy's Stars of Dance segment. He has also been a special guest of ''[[Drew Carey's Improv-A-Ganza]]'' on [[Game Show Network|GSN]]. Brady made a cameo in the 2011 song "Dedication To My Ex (Miss That)" by [[Lloyd (singer)|Lloyd]] featuring [[Lil Wayne]] and [[Andre 3000]], narrating Lil Wayne's section of the song. He appeared as a special guest star in the March 14, 2012, episode of the TV series ''[[Psych (TV series)|Psych]]''. Brady starred in the 2012 ABC improvisational comedy series ''[[Trust Us with Your Life]]'', and returned for the revival of ''Whose Line Is It Anyway?'' in the summer of 2013.{{cite web|title=About this show: Trust us with your life|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/showatch/trust-us-with-your-life/|publisher=The Futon Critic|accessdate=July 7, 2012}}{{cite news|last=Ng|first=Philiana|title='Whose Line Is It Anyway?' Being Revived by The CW|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/line-is-being-revived-by-425622#|accessdate=January 14, 2018|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=March 1, 2013}} Brady guest-starred as Don in the ''[[Phineas and Ferb]]'' episode "Where's Pinky?" on June 7, 2013, and for one week, February 9 to 13, 2015, [[List of The Late Late Show episodes (2015 guest hosts)|guest-hosted]] ''[[The Late Late Show (CBS TV series)|The Late Late Show]]'' on CBS. In November 2015, Brady replaced Billy Porter as Lola in ''[[Kinky Boots (musical)|Kinky Boots]]'' on Broadway.{{cite web|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Breaking-News-Emmy-Winner-Wayne-Brady-Will-Succeed-Billy-Porter-in-Broadways-KINKY-BOOTS-20150813|title=Breaking News: Emmy Winner Wayne Brady Will Succeed Billy Porter in Broadway's ''Kinky Boots''|author=BWW News Desk|work=BroadwayWorld.com|accessdate=September 2, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/2015/11/wayne-brady-kinky-boots-costume-photos|title=Exclusive: See Wayne Brady Make His Drag Debut in Kinky Boots|author=Alex Beggs|date=November 2, 2015|work=''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]''|accessdate=December 4, 2015}} Brady assumed the lead role of [[Aaron Burr]] in the [[PrivateBank Theatre]] production of ''[[Hamilton (musical)|Hamilton]]'' in Chicago from January 17 to April 9, 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/7648033/wayne-brady-hamilton-chicago-aaron-burr|title=Wayne Brady to Star in 'Hamilton' Chicago Run|last=Lee|first=Ashley|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=January 9, 2017|accessdate=January 9, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Its-Official-Wayne-Brady-Will-Play-Aaron-Burr-in-Chicagos-HAMILTON-20170116|title=Wayne Brady Takes First Bows as 'Aaron Burr' in Chicago's ''Hamilton'' Tonight|date=January 17, 2017|website=Broadway World|access-date=July 16, 2018}} On April 29, 2018, Brady won the Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Game Show Host for ''Let's Make A Deal''. ==Personal life== [[File:"VOICE AWARDS-2015" (21410691709).jpg|thumb|right|Brady and Taketa in 2015]] Brady has been married twice. He married Diana Lasso on December 31, 1993. They divorced on September 21, 1995. On April 3, 1999, he married dancer Mandie Taketa. He and Taketa have one child, a daughter named Maile Masako Brady, born on February 3, 2003. Brady and Taketa separated on April 5, 2006, and Taketa filed for divorce on July 2, 2007.{{cite web|title=Comic Wayne Brady, Wife Divorcing|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20044571,00.html|work=People|accessdate=September 30, 2011}} In 2007, Brady became an official supporter of [[Ronald McDonald House Charities]] and is a member of their celebrity board, the Friends of RMHC.{{cite web|url=http://www.rmhc.com/celebrity-friends|title=Celebrity Friends of RMHC|publisher=McDonald's Corporation|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081121005440/http://rmhc.com/celebrity-friends|archivedate=2008-11-21}} In 2013, [[Bill Maher]] compared Brady to President [[Barack Obama]], in that they were both supposedly "not black enough". Brady took issue with this statement, suggesting that Maher should "be careful when [he makes] statements like that" because it will allow his viewers to make the same stereotypical assumptions about black people.{{cite web|url=http://www.mediaite.com/tv/wayne-brady-calls-bullsht-on-bill-maher-i-will-beat-your-ass-in-public-for-questioning-my-black-cred|title=Wayne Brady Calls ‘Bullsh*t’ On Bill Maher: ‘I Will Beat Your Ass In Public’ For Questioning My Black Cred|date=May 15, 2013|work=mediaite.com|accessdate=September 2, 2015}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/13/wayne-brady-to-bill-maher_n_3268077.html|title=Wayne Brady To Bill Maher: 'I Will Beat Your Ass In Public' (VIDEO)|date=May 13, 2013|work=Huffington Post|access-date=July 16, 2018|language=en-US}} As a child, Wayne struggled with [[stuttering]] due to a great deal of [[anxiety]] he felt from being [[Bullying|bullied]] by other children.{{cite web|last1=Herard|first1=Cathy|title=Dr Oz: Wayne Brady Stuttering Struggle & Rachael Ray Vocal Cord Cyst|url=http://www.wellbuzz.com/dr-oz-womens-health-2/dr-oz-wayne-brady-stuttering-struggle-rachael-ray-vocal-cord-cyst|website=WellBuzz|publisher=WellBuzz|accessdate=July 12, 2015}} Wayne has [[Major depressive disorder|clinical depression]] and he had a [[mental breakdown]] on his 42nd birthday. He credits Taketa for helping him recover.{{cite web|last1=Bueno|first1=Antoinette|title=Wayne Brady Opens Up About His Depression: 'I Had a Complete Breakdown'|url=http://www.etonline.com/news/153335_wayne_brady_opens_up_about_his_depression/index.html|website=Entertainment Tonight|accessdate=November 4, 2014|date=November 3, 2014}} ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable ! | Year ! | Title ! | Role ! | Notes |- | 2003 || ''[[The Electric Piper]]'' || Sly (voice) || Television film |- | 2004 || ''[[Clifford's Really Big Movie]]'' || Shackelford (voice) || |- | 2004 || ''[[Going to the Mat]]'' || Mason Wyatt || |- | 2005 || ''[[Roll Bounce]]'' || D.J. Johnny Feelgood || |- | 2005 || ''[[Stuart Little 3: Call of the Wild]]'' || Reeko (voice) || Direct-to-video |- | 2007 || ''[[The List (2007 comedy film)|The List]]'' || Lewis || |- | 2012 || ''[[Foodfight!]]'' || Daredevil Dan (voice) || |- | 2013 || ''[[Scooby-Doo! Stage Fright]]'' || Brik Pimlento (voice) || Direct-to-video |- | 2013 || ''[[1982 (film)|1982]]'' || Alonzo || |- | 2014 || ''[[The Hero of Color City]]'' || Blue (voice) || |- | 2015 || ''[[VeggieTales]]: Noah's Ark'' || Shem (voice) || Direct-to-video |- | 2016 || ''[[Todrick Hall]]: Straight Outta Oz'' || Todrick's Father || Visual Album |} ===Television=== {| class="wikitable ! | Year ! | Title ! | Role ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Notes |- | 1990 || ''[[Superboy (TV series)|Superboy]]'' || John || Episode: "The Sons of Icarus" |- | 1993 || ''[[I'll Fly Away (TV series)|I'll Fly Away]]'' || Damon || 2 episodes |- | 1993 || ''[[In the Heat of the Night (TV series)|In the Heat of the Night]]'' || Henry Ulmer || Episode: "Hatton's Turn" (Parts 1 & 2) |- | 1997{{ndash}}1999 || ''[[Kwik Witz]]'' || Himself || Syndicated improv |- | 1998 || ''[[Whose Line Is It Anyway? (UK TV series)|Whose Line Is It Anyway?]]'' (UK) || Himself || 3 episodes in series 10 |- | 1998{{ndash}}2006,

Also executive producer (season 9–) |- | 1999, 2000 || ''[[The Drew Carey Show]]'' || Himself || "Drew Live" and "Drew Live II" (improv episodes) |- | 2000 || ''[[Batman Beyond]]'' || Micron || Episode: "The Call" (Parts 1 & 2) |- | 2000 || ''[[Geppetto (film)|Geppetto]]'' || The Magician || [[Television film|Movie]] |- | 2001{{ndash}}2004 || ''[[The Wayne Brady Show]]'' || Host || Variety show |- | 2002 || ''[[Miss America 2003|Miss America]]'' || Host || |- | 2004 || ''[[Chappelle's Show]]'' || Himself || 2 episodes |- | 2004 || ''[[Sesame Street]]'' || Himself || |- | 2005 || ''[[Stargate SG-1]]'' || Trelak || Episode: "[[Stargate_SG-1_(season_8)#Episodes|It's Good to be King]]" |- | 2006{{ndash}}2008 || ''[[Everybody Hates Chris]]'' || Louis || 2 episodes |- | 2006 || ''[[Robot Chicken]]'' || [[Pegasus]] 'Sunny Muffin' / Salam Fayyad (voice) || Episode: "Adoption's an Option" |- | 2006 || ''[[Crossover (2006 film)|Crossover]]'' || Vaughn || |- | 2006 || ''[[Shorty McShorts' Shorts]]'' || Cameron || Voice; 3 episodes |- | 2006{{ndash}}2014 || ''[[How I Met Your Mother]]'' || James Stinson || 13 episodes |- | 2007 || ''[[30 Rock]]'' || Steven Black || Episode: "The Source Awards" |- | 2007 || ''[[Dirt (TV series)|Dirt]]'' || Henchman || Episode: "You Don't Know Jack" |- | 2007{{ndash}}2009 || ''[[Don't Forget the Lyrics!]]'' || Host || |- | 2009{{ndash}}present || ''[[Let's Make a Deal]]'' || Host || |- | 2011 || ''[[Fast and Loose (2011 TV series)|Fast and Loose]]'' || Himself || UK improv; 2 episodes |- | 2011 || ''[[Are We There Yet? (TV series)|Are We There Yet?]]'' || Devin || Episode: "The Man and the Bragging Snafu Episode" |- | 2011 || ''[[Drew Carey's Improv-A-Ganza]]'' || Himself || 5 episodes |- | 2012{{ndash}}2013 || ''[[American Dad!]]'' || [[Cuba Gooding Jr.]] / Tungee (voice) || 3 episodes |- | 2012 || ''[[Trust Us with Your Life]]'' || Himself || 7 episodes |- | 2012 || ''[[Psych]]'' || Hilton Fox || Episode: "Shawn and the Real Girl" |- | 2013{{ndash}}present || ''[[Sofia the First]]'' || Clover the Rabbit || Voice role |- | 2013 || ''[[The Problem Solverz]]'' || Uncle Chocofuss || Guest voice actor |- | 2013 || ''[[So You Think You Can Dance]]'' || Himself/Guest judge || 2 episodes |- | 2014 || ''[[Hollywood Game Night]]'' || Himself || Episode: "50 Charades of Grey" |- | 2014 || ''[[So You Think You Can Dance]]'' || Himself/Guest judge ||{{cite web|url = http://castingmaster.com/so-you-think-you-can-dance-casting-guide/|title = ''So You Think You Can Dance'' – 2014 Casting Guide with Call Dates|accessdate = June 19, 2014}} |- | 2015 || ''[[The Late Late Show (CBS TV series)|The Late Late Show]]'' || Himself/Guest host || 5 episodes |- | 2016 || ''[[Aftermath (2016 TV series)|Aftermath]]'' || Lamar 'Booner' Boone || 2 episodes |- | 2016{{ndash}}present || ''[[The Loud House]]'' || [[Howard and Harold McBride|Harold McBride]] || Recurring voice role |- | 2018 || ''[[Colony (TV series)]]'' || Everett Kynes || |} === Theatre credits === {| class="wikitable" !Year(s) !Production !Role !Theater !Location |- | 2004 | ''[[Chicago (musical)|Chicago]]'' | Billy Flynn |[[Ambassador Theatre (New York City)|Ambassador Theatre]] |[[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] |- | 2010 | ''[[Rent (musical)|Rent]]'' | Tom Collins |[[Hollywood Bowl]] |Los Angeles |- | 2015–16
March–April 2018 | ''[[Kinky Boots (musical)|Kinky Boots]]'' | Lola |[[Al Hirschfeld Theatre]] |Broadway |- |2016||''[[White Rabbit, Red Rabbit]]||solo||[[Westside Theatre]]||[[off-Broadway]][https://www.today.com/popculture/wayne-brady-talks-kinky-boots-white-rabbit-red-rabbit-t75781 "Wayne Brady talks ''Kinky Boots'' and ''White Rabbit, Red Rabbit''], ''[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]]'', February 25, 2016 |- | 2016 | ''[[Merrily We Roll Along (musical)|Merrily We Roll Along]]'' | Charley Kringas |[[Wallis Annenberg Center for the Performing Arts]] |Los Angeles |- |2017 | ''[[Hamilton (musical)|Hamilton]]'' | [[Aaron Burr]] |[[PrivateBank Theatre]] | Chicago |} === Video games === {| class="wikitable" !Year !Title !Role !Notes |- |2008 |''[[The Legend of Spyro: Dawn of the Dragon]]'' |Sparx | |} ==Discography== '''Albums''' {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2"| Album details ! colspan="3"| Chart positions |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! style="width:40px;"| [[Billboard 200|US]] ! style="width:40px;"| [[Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums|US

Stop"{{spaced ndash}}Jamie Jones featuring Wayne Brady and William Carthright * 2008 ** "[[Ordinary (Wayne Brady song)|Ordinary]]" * 2009 ** "F.W.B." * 2013 ** "Whistle While I Work it"{{spaced ndash}}[[Chester See]] featuring [[Tobuscus]] with Wayne Brady ==Awards and nominations== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" ! scope="col" | Year ! scope="col" | Association ! scope="col" | Category Music Program|Outstanding Individual Performance in a Variety or Music Program]] || rowspan=3| ''Whose Line Is It Anyway?'' || {{nom}} |- | 2002 || {{nom}} |- | 2003 || {{won}} |- | 2003 || rowspan=2| || Outstanding Game Show Host || {{nom}} |- | 2013 || Outstanding Game Show Host || {{nom}} |- | 2014 || Outstanding Game Show Host || {{nom}} |- | 2014 || [[41st Daytime Creative Arts Emmy
